sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving solutions
message_1:
What is the standard enthalpy change for the following reaction at 298 K, given the molar enthalpies of the reactants and products?

2NaOH (aq) + H2SO4 (aq) → Na2SO4 (aq) + 2H2O (l)

Molar enthalpy of NaOH (aq) = -470.60 kJ/mol
Molar enthalpy of H2SO4 (aq) = -813.22 kJ/mol
Molar enthalpy of Na2SO4 (aq) = -1387.99 kJ/mol
Molar enthalpy of H2O (l) = -285.83 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the formula:

ΔH_reaction = Σ ΔH_products - Σ ΔH_reactants

For the products, we have:
1 mol of Na2SO4 (aq) and 2 mol of H2O (l)

For the reactants, we have:
2 mol of NaOH (aq) and 1 mol of H2SO4 (aq)

Now, we can plug in the given molar enthalpies:

ΔH_reaction = [(1 × -1387.99) + (2 × -285.83)] - [(2 × -470.60) + (1 × -813.22)]

ΔH_reaction = [-1387.99 + (-571.66)] - [(-941.20) + (-813.22)]

ΔH_reaction = (-1959.65) - (-1754.42)

ΔH_reaction = -205.23 kJ

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction at 298 K is -205.23 kJ.
